templateElements.name: childIsAdult
templateElements.title: Is {panel.childName} 19 years of age or older?

templateElements.name: childIsAdultNoExplanation
templateElements.title:
Because {panel.childName} is under the age of 19, the Public Guardian and Trustee (PGT) needs to be notified in addition to {panel.childName}'s parent or guardian.

The PGT requires additional information. This service will let you know what additional information is required at a later stage.

templateElements.name: childHasCommittee
templateElements.title: Does {panel.childName} have a committee?
templateElements.description: If someone has been declared mentally incompetent by a court, a committee (or equivalent), will have been appointed to take care of the mentally incompetent person's finances.

templateElements.name: childCommitteeName

templateElements.title: Full name of person most likely to manage {panel.childName}'s money and belongings.

templateElements.name: childDied5DaysAfter
templateElements.title: Did {panel.childName} die after {deceasedDateOfDeathPlus4}?

templateElements.name: childDied5DaysAfterFAQ1
templateElements.title: Why does this date matter?
templateElements.body:
In determining who gets part of estate, it is important to know who died first. This may not sound strange, but under the law, if they died less than 5 days after Deceased Name, they are considered to have died before Deceased Name. For more information, refer to Five-day survival rule from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA).
http://www.bclaws.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/00_09013_01#section10
